species_profile.animal_facts:
The Asian Elephant, a central part of many Southeast Asian cultures, is in slow decline.
Despite their huge size wild elephants are elusive, spending much of their time deep in the forests feeding on young palm and bamboo shoots and fresh leaves. In areas recently converted from forest to agricultural land herds of elephants cause great damage to crops and fruit orchards in their search for food, especially bananas. Elephants may spend up to 14–19 hrs a day feeding, during which they may consume up to 150 kg of wet weight. They defecate about 16–18 times a day, producing about 100 kg of dung. Dung also helps disperse germinating seeds. They are also a premier “flagship species” and are sometimes regarded as a “keystone species” because of their important ecological role and impact on the environment.
Females are generally docile, but large males can be aggressive. Males have tusks up to 1.5 metres long. They are active by day and night, and are able swimmers.
The life span of Asian elephants is 60 to 70 years, and males reach sexual maturity at between 10–15 years of age; females usually first give birth in years 15 or 16. The male can grow to reach a height of 2.6m and the female 2.2m.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Bangladesh; Bhutan; Cambodia; China; India; Indonesia (Kalimantan, Sumatera); Lao People’s Democratic Republic; Malaysia (Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah); Myanmar; Nepal; Sri Lanka; Thailand; Vietnam.
species_profile.habitat: Asian elephants are generalists and they occur in grassland, tropical evergreen forest, semi-evergreen forest, moist deciduous forest, dry deciduous forested and dry thorn forest, in addition to cultivated and secondary forests and scrublands. Over this range of habitat types elephants are seen from sea level to over 3,000m at sea level.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Given their physiology and energy requirements, elephants need to consume large quantities of food per day. They are generalists and browse and graze on a variety of plants. The proportions of the different plant types in their diet vary depending upon the habitat and season.
species_profile.threatened_by: Habitat loss, degradation, and fragmentation which are driven by an expanding human population, and lead in turn to increasing conflicts between humans and elephants when elephants eat or trample crops. Poaching for ivory is also a major threat to the elephant.
species_profile.image_title: Asian Elephant Elephas maximus by berniedup, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
It is nocturnal and mainly terrestrial in habits, but is recognised as a good climber and is known to rest by day either in holes in the ground or in tree holes. The fur of the banded palm civet is one of the most distinctively marked of all civet species. Its patterning is unmistakable, comprising a buff to brown body colour adorned with a series of 7 or 8 tapering dark bars across the back. The face is patterned with dark stripes and the neck with broken dark bands.
The banded palm civet is solitary animal that only comes out under the cover of night to hunt and catch food. These nocturnal animals are primarily ground-dwelling and highly territorial. Despite being predominately ground-dwelling though the banded palm civet is known to climb up into the trees either in search of food or to hide from approaching predators.
The female banded palm civet usually gives birth to up to a maximum of 4 young after a gestation period that lasts for a couple of months. The babies are weaned by their mother until they are strong enough to fend for themselves. Banded palm civets can live for up to 20 years, although most rarely get to be this old.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Indonesia (Kalimantan, Sumatera); Malaysia (Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, Sarawak); Myanmar; Thailand.
species_profile.habitat: Primary lowland rainforest, but also in disturbed habitat, peat swamp forest and acacia plantations In Borneo, it was found at elevations up to 1,200 m.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Insects, small animals such as rodents, lizards, snakes and frogs.
species_profile.who_eats_them: Humans large snakes and big cats such as the leopard.
species_profile.threatened_by: Human settlement expansion and creation of plantations causing habitat loss and degradation. They are also hunted for food.
species_profile.image_title: Banded civet by Just chaos, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
These animals are incredibly alert and get their name from the barking alarm call made when threatened they are also known as the Bornean red muntjac.
They are a relatively common deer and are mostly diurnal although have been known to exhibit nocturnal activity as well. They are mostly solitary animals that are very territorial, they can defend themselves effectively even against dogs.
They have short, thick dense coats; the males have short antlers that can regrow if lost through fighting, they also have slightly elongated canines about an inch long, these curve upwards from the lips and can inflict serious injury. The females instead of antlers have tufts of hair and small bony knobs.
They give birth to one fawn (occasionally twins) after a gestation of 6-7 months and can reproduce throughout the year. The young will leave its mother at around six months of age and become sexually mature at 1-2 years old.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand.
species_profile.habitat: Associated with forests, occur widely even in heavily degraded forests and places adjacent to forests such as plantations (coffee, rubber, sugarcane, cassava, coconut and teak).
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Their diet consists of mostly fruits, buds, slender leaves, flowers, herbs and young grass.
species_profile.who_eats_them: Tigers, leopards, birds of prey and humans.
species_profile.threatened_by: Habitat encroachment and hunting, the latter has increased alongside logging. Sought after wild meat, skins are also used and a source of traditional medicine.
species_profile.image_title: Indian Muntjac (Muntiacus muntjak) by Tarique Sani, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Bearded pigs get their name from the yellowish whiskers on the side of the face and over the bridge of the nose. These form the “beard” after which this pig is named. The latin word Sus means ‘pig’ and barbatus means ‘bearded’. There are two currently recognised bearded pig species.
They live in stable family groups. After a gestation of about 4 months, the female makes a nest of plant material and gives birth to 3-11 young. They stay with her for about a year. When the piglets are born they have a stripy coat. This acts as camouflage and helps to protect them from predation as they hide in the bushes.
These pigs like to move about a lot and can travel as far as 22km in a month. These pigs are not afraid of getting wet as they regularly swim across rivers, sometimes coastal bays and even out to sea!
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Malaysia and the islands of Sumatra and Borneo in Asia.
species_profile.habitat: Tropical forest and mangroves.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Fruits, roots, tubers, seedlings, earthworms and carrion (dead meat). They are omnivores.
species_profile.who_eats_them: The main predators of Bearded pigs are tiger, leopard, clouded leopard, python and humans.
species_profile.threatened_by: The Bearded Pig is a local food source. Their meat is culturally and economically important and therefore it is the most frequently hunted wildlife species in the area. Improved access into the forests and destruction of their natural habitats by logging and agricultural activities has increased hunting pressure on the Bearded pigs.
species_profile.image_title: Bearded Pigs Sus barbatus by berniedup, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
The Binturong, which is the Malay name for “bear cat,” is a carnivore related to the palm civets. It looks like a large shaggy mongoose. The hair on its tail is longer than that on the body, and tufts of long hair sprout from the backs of the ears. The fur is black sprinkled with brown or grey on the tips of the hairs. The long whiskers, the ear tufts, and sometimes the face are white. They are nocturnal and excellent climbers. 
They belong to the same family as other small carnivores including Civets, Genets, Mongooses and Fossa and share a number of characteristics with them including a long snout and having more teeth than most other carnivorous mammals. Like other members of the Civet family, the Binturong has scent glands which are located just under it’s tail. These glands are used to mark trees and foliage to outline an individual’s territory and is distributed whilst the Binturong is moving about. Oddly enough, the odour of this scent is said to smell like popcorn as are Binturong cubs when they are newborn. Until they became stronger and are more aware of their surroundings, young Binturong are incredibly vulnerable and are able to spray foul smelling liquid (like a Skunk) when they are really frightened. When climbing, the Binturong is actually able to rotate it’s hind legs backwards so that their claws still have a good grip when climbing down a tree head first.
After a gestation period that lasts for around 3 months and has a litter of 1-3 cubs. They reach their adult size after a year. The Binturong is thought to live for between 10 and 15 years. Binturongs measure up to six feet in overall length, and weigh up to 30 pounds.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Bangladesh; Bhutan; Brunei Darussalam; Cambodia; China; India; Indonesia (Jawa, Kalimantan, Sumatera); Lao People’s Democratic Republic; Malaysia (Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, Sarawak); Myanmar; Nepal; Philippines; Thailand; Vietnam.
species_profile.habitat: Tall forest, evergreen forest, In the Philippines, the species is found in primary and secondary lowland forest, including grassland/forest mosaic from sea level to 400 m.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Mainly fruit, although they are also known to hunt insects, birds, fish and rodents.
species_profile.who_eats_them: Tigers and Snakes would pose the biggest threat to the Binturong adults, along with Birds of Prey and small carnivores that could easily target one of the young cubs.
species_profile.threatened_by: The major threats facing this specie include; the pet trade, human consumption and habitat loss; particularly in the more southern parts of it’s natural range. The biggest threat to the world’s Binturong population though is people via deforestation and expanding human populations.
species_profile.image_title: Binturong by Chi Liu, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as the Müller’s Bornean Gibbon, Bornean Grey Gibbon, Borneo Gibbon, Grey Gibbon, and Müller’s Gibbon. The species is endemic to Borneo, and is confined to tall primary rainforest in lowland and lower montane areas. The fur colour of the Bornean Gibbon is typically grey-brown, though this can vary greatly. The brow is pale cream to white.
Gibbons are exclusively diurnal and arboreal, and rearly descend to the ground. They travel mostly in trees by swinging from branch to branch via brachiation. This mode of locomotion involves extending their long arms over their head in order to hook their hands onto branches.  They are able to cover three meters in a single swing and around 850 meters per day. Bornean gibbons walk upright with hands over head for balance when walking on the ground, although they do not cover long distances in this fashion. They are not good swimmers and avoid open water.
Gibbons are monogamous and occur in small family groups generally comprising a male, female and their young. Most gibbons produce offspring every 2 to 3 years. Nursing may last as long as two years. Because young typically stay with their parents until they reach maturity. It is thought their life span in up to 25 years in the wild.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam; Indonesia (Kalimantan); Malaysia (Sabah).
species_profile.habitat: Tropical evergreen forests of primary, selectively logged and secondary forest types.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Fruits high in sugar, immature leaves and insects.
species_profile.threatened_by: Human settlement expansion and creation of plantations causing habitat loss and degradation. Hunted for food and the pet trade.
species_profile.image_title: Mueller's Gibbon by Chi Liu, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
One of the smallest in the slow loris family they are recognised by their pale golden to reddish fur and lack of markings on the face. As with all slow loris’ they have a vestigial tail, round head, short ears and a curved toilet claw for grooming. Additionally they have a gland that produces an oily toxin used in defence.
A nocturnal primate who is predominantly arboreal and generally occur in low densities making them difficult to come by but have been observed singly, as mother offspring pairs or in adult trios.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Found in Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines.
species_profile.habitat: Primary and secondary lowland forest, gardens and plantations, locals have seen them in citrus trees, maybe tolerant to variety of habitats.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Little known about their diet but believed to eat insects, some small mammals and pulpy fruits. Also been observed eating gum (tree sap) from woody plants.
species_profile.threatened_by: Habitat loss through burning and alteration in particular oil palm plantations, relatively adaptable but severe forest loss in its region must have had some negative impacts. Collected locally as pets.
species_profile.image_title: Bornean Slow Loris by mishko2007, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Orangutans are the largest arboreal mammal on earth today. They are semi-solitary with a complex community based on loose relationships. They are believed to be the ‘gardeners’ of the forest as they play a vital role in seed dispersal, especially large seeds. They are highly dependent on fruit and its availability directly affects all aspects of their life, including ranging patterns, seasonal movements, and health, social and reproductive behaviour.
They are the only primates to have 2 different forms of mature males; firstly the flanged male (small inset picture) who has a long coat of dark hair on his back, facial disks, flanges and a throat sack for making ‘long calls’ – they are generally aggressive to and intolerant of other males. Secondly, there is the un-flanged males who are similar to an adult female in size and appearance, do not omit long calls and are more tolerant. Both types of male are successful reproductively.
Females mature at the age of 10-15 years old and will reproduce every 6-8 years thereafter. They will give birth to a single infant after a pregnancy of approximately 245 days.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Endemic to Borneo, present in 2 Malaysian states (Sabah and Sarawak) and in 3 of the 4 Indonesian provinces.
species_profile.habitat: Low lying forest including flood prone forests and peat swamps.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Eat more than 500 species of plant, and fruits make up 60% of their average intake. Diet includes leaves, bark, fruit, flowers and insects.
species_profile.threatened_by: Habitat loss to agriculture (oil palm), fires, illegal logging, habitat exploitation and fragmentation, hunting (bush meat and traditional medicine) and illegal pet trade.
species_profile.image_title: Orang Utan Male Pongo pygmaeus by berniedup, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as the fishing owl. They live near water and eat fish as well as small mammals and birds. They are distinguished by their brilliant yellowish eyes and prominent ear-tufts, usually tilted at 45 degrees.  They possess a diagnostic white patch above the bill, distinguished from Brown Fish Owl by its darker plumage with thicker black streaks. It can grow as tall as 50cm.
It is nocturnal and terrestrial in habit. It rests in a tree during the day until dusk when it leaves in search of food. They feed on fish, frogs and crustaceans near streams, as well as bats and small birds. Sharp spicules on the underside of its toes enables the owl to grab on to slippery fish. While silent flight is a hallmark of owls’ mastery of nocturnal hunting, the buffy fish owl and its relatives have actually lost the soft fringes that are found along the rear edge of the wing feathers in other owl species, which enables owls to fly without making a single sound. Since fishes don’t pick up airborne sounds very well, there is little need for the buffy fish owl to conceal the sound of its approach as it swoops in for the kill.
Buffy fish owls do not build their own nests, but rather use the abandoned nests of other birds or a tree cavity. The female lays one egg, which hatches approximately one month later. A mature adult is approximately 20 inches (43 to 50 cm) in length and has a wingspan of 17 inches (36 cm).
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Bangladesh; Brunei Darussalam; Cambodia; Indonesia; Lao People’s Democratic Republic; Malaysia; Myanmar; Singapore; Thailand; Vietnam.
species_profile.habitat: Subtropical or tropical moist montanes.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Fish, lizards and small rodents.
species_profile.threatened_by: Not currently threatened.
species_profile.image_title: Buffy Fish-Owl (Ketupa ketupu) by John Bakar - Johnnizam, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as the Sunda Clouded Leopard, Enkuli Clouded Leopard, Sunda Islands Clouded Leopard, and the Sundaland Clouded Leopard.  The clouded leopard is the smallest of the big cats, they are secretive and rare in the wild, preferring to remain alone and hidden from view. The hind feet possess flexible ankle joints that allow the foot to rotate backwards as well. Clouded leopards are one of the best climbers in the cat family.Classically considered a single species, the Clouded Leopard has recently been split into two species. Based on analysis of mitochondrial DNA, microsatellites and morphology, Neofelis nebulosa is restricted to mainland Southeast Asia, and N. diardi is found on the islands of Sumatra and Borneo. 
Clouded leopards are a medium-sized cat named for the cloud-like spots on its coat. These provide camouflage in the dappled light of its forest habitat. (In China the cat is known as the ‘Mint Leopard’ because its spots can also look like mint leaves). The cats usually stand 10-16 inches (25-40cm) tall and are 4 to 6 feet (1.2-1.8m) long, almost half of which is the tail. Males tend to be larger and weigh up to 50 pounds (23 kg), while females weigh about 35 pounds (16 kg). Clouded leopards can live to about 17 years old in captivity but will struggle to reach 12 in the wild. 
Clouded leopards are sexually mature around the age of 2 years. The gestation period is 85 to 93 days long with 1 to 5 cubs per litter, although 2 is the most common number. Females can produce a litter every year. Cubs become independent at approximately 10 months of age.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam; Indonesia (Kalimantan, Sumatera); Malaysia (Sabah, Sarawak).
species_profile.habitat: Lowland tropical rain forest.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Young sambar deer, barking deer, mouse deer, bearded pig, palm civet, gray leaf monkey, fish and porcupine.
species_profile.who_eats_them: Nothing but are threatened by other big cats.
species_profile.threatened_by: Deforestation, with oil palm plantations expanding rapidly, as well as logging and clearance for agriculture and settlement . There is substantial illegal trade in clouded leopard skins.
species_profile.image_title: Bornean Clouded Leopard by canorus, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also named the Sunda Flying Lemur or the Malayan Flying Lemur.  The Sunda Flying Lemur, also known as the Malayan Flying Lemur, is a species of colugo, not lemur. Until recently, it was thought to be one of only two species of flying lemur, the other being the Philippine Flying Lemur which is found only in the Philippines. It is comparable to a medium-sized possum or a very large squirrel. They have moderately long, slender limbs of equal length front and rear, a medium-length tail, and a relatively light build. The head is small, with large, front-focused eyes for excellent binocular vision, and small, rounded ears. Their most distinctive feature is the membrane of skin that extends between their limbs and gives them the ability to glide long distances between trees.
It is strictly arboreal and nocturnal. Head-body length of Sunda Flying Lemur is about 34 to 38 cm. Its tail length is around 24 to 25 cm and weight is 0.9 to 1.3 kg.
Although they are placental mammals, colugos are marsupial-like in their breeding habits. The young are born after 60 days of gestation in a tiny and undeveloped form, and spend their first six months or so of life clinging to the mother’s belly. To protect them and transport them she curls her tail up to fold the gliding membrane into a warm, secure quasi-pouch. Breeding is fairly slow as the young do not reach full size until they are two or three years old.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam; Cambodia; Indonesia; Lao People’s Democratic Republic; Malaysia; Myanmar; Singapore; Thailand; Vietnam.
species_profile.habitat: Lowland tropical rain forest.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Herbivorous: leaves, shoots, flowers and sap,  fruit. They have well-developed stomachs and long intestines, capable of extracting nutriment from leaves.
species_profile.threatened_by: The Sunda Flying Lemur is protected by national legislation. In addition to deforestation and loss of habitat, local subsistence hunting poses a serious threat to this animal. Competition with the Plantain squirrel (Callosciurus notatus) represents another challenge for this species.
species_profile.image_title: Colugo - Observing with curiosity by Dzulhelmi Nasir, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as Musang, Toddy Cat. A nocturnal omnivore, the palm civet hunts alone. They are expert climbers and spend most of their lives in trees. This species is adapted for forest living, yet it tolerates living in areas near humans; sleeping in barns, drains, or roofs during the day, and coming out at night to catch rats or forage for mango, coffee, pineapples, melons, and bananas, it also eats insects and molluscs.  The palm civet is also fond of coffee cherries. They eat the outer fruit and the coffee beans pass through their digestive tract. An expensive coffee called kopi luwak is supposedly made from these coffee beans. Kopi luwak is said to have a gamy flavor and sells for more than $100 per pound.
Weighing from 4 to 11 pounds, the palm civet’s head and body length is 17 to 28 inches (43.2-71 cm), with a tail length of 16 to 26 inches (40.6-66 cm). Its ears are small and faintly pointed, as is its nose. It has a long and slender body with short legs. They have a coarse grayish to brown coat with black-tipped guard hairs over all. Three rows of black spots run along each side of its body. The hair around its eyes, cheeks and muzzle is black, with spots of white under each eye and on each side of its nose. The ears, feet and last end of its tail are also black.
Both sexes have well-developed anal scent glands looking somewhat like testes, which gives the musang its species name.
Plam civets reproduce throughout the year although it has been recorded that kittens are most often seen from October to December. Kittens are born in a litter of 2 to 5 young. Palm civets become sexually mature at 11 to 12 months.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Bangladesh; Bhutan; Brunei Darussalam; Cambodia; China; India; Indonesia (Irian Jaya – Introduced, Jawa, Kalimantan, Lesser Sunda Is. – Introduced, Maluku – Introduced, Sulawesi – Introduced, Sumatera); Lao People’s Democratic Republic; Malaysia (Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, Sarawak); Myanmar; Nepal; Philippines; Singapore; Sri Lanka; Thailand; Vietnam.
species_profile.habitat: Wide range of habitats including evergreen and deciduous forest (primary and secondary), plantations and near humans, in habitats up to 2,400 m.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: They eat small vertebrates, insects, ripe fruits and seeds. They are very fond of palm sap, therefore their common name. The sap is used by natives to make a sweet liquor called “toddy”, which gives the palm civet its other common name. The palm civet is also fond of coffee cherries.
species_profile.who_eats_them: Birds of prey and large carnivores.
species_profile.threatened_by: In some parts of its range this species is hunted for bush meat and the pet trade. In South China it is extensively hunted and trapped. It is also persecuted as a pest though it seems able to tolerate very high levels of persecution.
species_profile.image_title: Asian Palm Civet (Paradoxurus hermaphroditus) by NeilKonradIII, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as the Malayan Porcupine and the Himalayan Crestless Porcupine. It is a large and stout bodied nocturnal rodent covered with quills which are sharp, rigid structures. The quills/spines are modified hair. The quills or spines on their upper body parts are rough with black and white or yellowed stripe in colour. The young’s soft quills become hard as they enter adulthood. It has short stocky legs covered in brown hairs which have four claws on the front and five on the hind legs. Both front and hind legs have smooth soles. The head and body measurement are around 63-72.5 cm and their tail is about 6–11 cm. Their weight is around 0.7 kg-2.4 kg.
Malayan porcupines create burrows which lead into huge networks of tunnels beneath their surrounding habitats, allowing them to get around during the daytime without being exposed to sunlight. It is found in various types of forest habitats as well as open areas near forests. It may stray into nearby agricultural areas. It digs into the ground and inhabits dens near rocky areas, where it lives in small groups. They live with other adults of their species and usually produce litters of two or three pups after a pregnancy of around 110 days.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Bangladesh; China; India; Indonesia; Lao People’s Democratic Republic; Malaysia; Myanmar; Nepal; Thailand; Vietnam.
species_profile.habitat: Forest habitats, and in scrubby, open areas close to forest.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Roots, tubers, bark and fallen fruits. They also eat carrion and insects.
species_profile.threatened_by: Hunted for food but this not thought to impact populations. In South Asia, it is threatened by habitat loss due to construction of dams, human settlements and other infrastructure development. It is harvested for subsistence food and medicinal purposes.
species_profile.image_title: Malayan Porcupine (Captive) by myrontay, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
The Crested Fireback, Lophura ignita, is a medium-sized, up to 70 cm long, forest pheasant with a peacock-like dark crest, bluish black plumage, reddish brown rump, black outer tail feathers, red iris and bare blue facial skin. Fireback pheasants are widely admired for their impressive facial decorations, which play an important role in courtship displays. The female is a brown bird with short crest, blue facial skin and spotted black-and-white below.
The males are approximately 67cm in length, and 28cm in wing length. The female is slightly smaller than the male.
They breed at the approximately age of 3. Usually in May through August. A typical Clutch Size is 4 to 8 eggs and are incubated for approximately 24 days. Males become particularly aggressive during breeding season.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam; Indonesia; Malaysia; Myanmar; Thailand.
species_profile.habitat: Lowland tropical rain forest.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Leaves, seeds, figs and insects.
species_profile.threatened_by: Forest destruction (logging & land conversion) in the Sundaic lowlands of Indonesia and Malaysia has been extensive, trapping for the cage-bird industry.
species_profile.image_title: Crested fireback, Lophura ignita by Jeremy Ringma, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts: The body colour of this lizard is bright green, sometimes with a bluish tinge on the head. It is able to change colour, turning darker brown when threatened. Males have an attractive neck crest. The tail makes up over 75 percent of its total length of 57cm.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Southeast Asia: Malaysia (West Malaysia and Borneo), Singapore, Indonesia, Philippines (Palawan, Calamian Islands, Panay, Luzon), South Thailand, South Myanmar (Tenasserim Hills), and India (Nicobar Islands).
species_profile.habitat: Primary and secondary forest.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Insects and other invertebrates.
species_profile.threatened_by: Persecution from superstition, harvest for the pet trade and habitat loss.
species_profile.image_title: Bronchocela cristatella by _Cheng Puay, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
The Flat-headed Cat takes its name from its unusually long, sloping snout and flattened skull roof, with small ears set well down the sides of its head. It is nocturnal and has large, close-set eyes, and relatively longer and sharper teeth than its close relatives. The thick fur is reddish-brown on top of the head, dark roan brown on the body, and mottled white on the underbelly. The face is lighter in colour than the body, and the muzzle and chin are white. Two prominent buff whitish streaks run on either side of the nose between the eyes. The teeth are adapted for gripping onto slippery prey, jaws that are relatively powerful and retractable claws. These features help the flat-headed cat to catch and retain aquatic prey, to which it is at least as well adapted as the fishing cat.
Flat-headed cats are presumably solitary, and probably maintain their home ranges by scent marking.
Very little is known about this species, with only a handful of observations and camera trap records. Available information suggests that, like its close relative the fishing cat, the flat-headed cat is strongly associated with wetlands and preys primarily on fish.
Their gestation period lasts about 56 days, litter sizes range from records of 1 to 2 kittens.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam; Indonesia (Kalimantan, Sumatera); Malaysia (Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, Sarawak); Thailand.
species_profile.habitat: Wetlands and lowland forests.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Fish, shrimp,  domestic poultry.
species_profile.threatened_by: Wetland and lowland forest destruction and degradation is the primary threat faced by the species Causes of this destruction include human settlement, forest transformation to plantations, draining for agriculture, pollution, and excessive hunting, wood-cutting and fishing.
species_profile.image_title: Flat-headed Cat Zoo Melaka by nature24, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
The Red Giant Flying Squirrel is amongst the largest of flying squirrels in Southeast Asia. It is characterised by its dark red colouring and large eyes. When compared to other species of squirrels, this species is large, being on average 42 cm long. Entire body dark reddish except for black on nose, chin, eye-ring, behind the ears, feet and tail tip. Petaurista petaurista possibly represents a complex of several similar species.
It is predominantly nocturnal and inhabits primary or tall secondary forest. It does not hibernate, but migrates to areas with more food.. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species.
Like all other species of flying squirrels, it has a membrane of skin between its legs, which is used to glide between trees.
It is able to glide for long distances. There have been reports of distances up to 75 metres (250 ft.) or greater; glide angles are generally 40-60 degrees from the horizontal, occasionally steeper for shorter glides. Their nest holes usually at least 10m above ground.
P. petaurista is most active between sunset and midnight and the home range of adult females in conifer plantation was estimated to be 3.2ha.
The Red Giant Flying Squirrel is believed to mate twice a year and the young are typically born in March or August in litters of two to three.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Afghanistan; Brunei Darussalam; China (Sichuan, Yunnan); India (Assam, Bihar, Himachal Pradesh, Jammu-Kashmir, Meghalaya, Punjab, Uttaranchal, Uttar Pradesh, West Bengal); Indonesia (Jawa, Kalimantan, Sumatera); Malaysia (Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, Sarawak); Myanmar; Nepal and Thailand.
species_profile.habitat: Moist evergreen broadleaf forest, temperate forest, coniferous forests, scrub forest, rocky areas as inland cliffs and mountain peaks.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Conifer cones, leaves and branches, and, when in season, fruits and nuts, and occasionally insects.
species_profile.threatened_by: Habitat conversion due to logging, agriculture, dam construction, infrastructure development and urbanization is occurring throughout the range of the species. It has been harvested for the pet and fur trade in South Asia.
species_profile.image_title: Yikes! So deep! by vil.sandi, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as the pale giant or cream coloured squirrel. It is a closed canopy species that is never seen on ground. It is one of the largest species of squirrel in the world. The head and back of the body varies from dark brown to gray, and the belly varies from dark yellow to white. The ears are short and round. The adult squirrel’s head and body is from 322 to 350 millimetres (12.7 to 14 in) in length, and the tail is 373 to 438 millimetres (14.7 to 17.2 in) long, with an overall length of 695 to 788 millimetres (27.4 to 31.0 in); the weight is between 929 to 1,575 grams (2.05 to 3.47 lb).
This species is diurnal, but mainly active during morning and evening. They live either in pairs or alone. Unlike other tree squirrels, the cream-coloured giant squirrel does not sit upright with its tail arched over its back while feeding; instead, it balances itself with its hind feet on a branch so that its hands are free to control its food. In this position the axis of the squirrels body is held at right angles to the support, with its head and forequarters on one side of the branch, and the tail as a counterweight on the other side.
Although this squirrel often will make holes in trees for shelter, during the breeding season it constructs a large globular drey (or nest) in tree branches, roughly the size of an eagle’s aerie. The young are born and raised in this nest.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam; Indonesia (Kalimantan, Sumatera); Malaysia (Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, Sarawak); Singapore; Thailand.
species_profile.habitat: Wet evergreen forests.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Mainly fruit seeds and leaves, sometimes on insects.
species_profile.image_title: Giant Squirrel (Ratufa affinis sandakanensis) by John Bakar - Johnnizam, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
The Great Argus was named by Carolus Linnaeus for the many eyes-like pattern on its wings. In Greek mythology, Argus is a hundred-eyed giant. It is also known as Phoenix in some Asian areas.
One of the most unusual of all bird species, males are unmistakable with massive primary, secondary and tail feathers. The face is blue, the crown is black with a distinctive short crest. The upperparts are brown, finely mottled with buff; iridescent ocelli can be found on the wings and tail. The wings can continue to grow until the bird reaches its sixth year. They are amongst the largest of all pheasants measuring up to 6.5 feet (~2m) in length. A. a. grayi is slightly smaller than A. a. argus and can be distingiused by the burnt orange on the breast and neck and with more white spotting. Females are similar, but smaller than males; also lack the ornate tail and wings.
The Great Argus’s breeding display is remarkable.  The male clears an open spot in the forest and prepares a dancing ground. He announces himself with loud calls to attract females, then he dances before her with his wings spread into two enormous fans, revealing the hundred of flashy “eye-spots” eyes.
The Great Argus is monogamous. They reach sexual maturity in three years. The Great argus produce two to four eggs per year. The newly-hatched chicks soon leave the nest area in company with their mother. Their wing feathers grow quickly, allowing them to fly long before they reach their adult size. The dispersal of their young is rather early.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam; Indonesia; Malaysia; Myanmar; Thailand.
species_profile.habitat: Occurs in tall, dry, lowland primary and logged forests, up to 1,300 m, but principally, below 900 m. It is much sparser in deciduous forest and rare to absent from lowland peat swamp and white-sand heath forests.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Fruit, seeds and insects.
species_profile.threatened_by: Forest destruction, including the escalation of logging and land conversion, with deliberate targeting of all remaining stands of valuable timber including those inside protected areas, plus forest fires (particularly in 1997-1998), and declines are compounded by trapping for the cage-bird industry.
species_profile.image_title: Great Argus-Argusianus argus Pheasant-Pheasant by dpfunsun, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as the asian brown tortoise, Asian Giant Tortoise, Asian Tortoise and Black Giant Tortoise, Burmese Brown Tortoise, Burmese Mountain Tortoise. This tortoise is the largest inhabiting Asia, and the fourth largest in the world. It has a carapace length of up to 50 cm and a weight of approximately 20kg.
The tortoise’s forelimbs have five large claws and are covered on the front with large, heavy, overlapping scales. By contrast, the hindlimbs end in four pointed claws and bare a conspicuous cluster of very large tubercular scales on the thigh either side of the tail. These are so large that the species is sometimes referred to as the six-footed tortoise. It spends most of the warmer parts of the day soaking in pools or in the shade, out of the sun’s rays.
The Asian tortoise is unique among turtles and tortoises in building a nest on the surface of the ground, and in providing maternal protection of the eggs. For a few days before laying, the female gathers up leaves and debris into a mound on which to place her clutch. Unlike most tortoises, which use their hindlimbs to excavate nest sites, Asian tortoises use their forelimbs to ‘backsweep’ surface leaf-litter. Reported clutch sizes in captivity range from 21 to 53 eggs, which the female then covers with vegetation and guards, frequently piling more vegetation on top. If the eggs are threatened by a potential predator, the female will first attempt to drive them away by pushing and biting, but if this fails, she then defends the eggs by sprawling her body over them. This behaviour normally lasts just a few days following egg-laying, although up to six weeks of nest-guarding has been recorded
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Assam in India, through Burma and Bangladesh to northern and west-central Thailand, while the Asian brown tortoise reportedly occurs in southern Thailand, Peninsula Malaysia, Sumatra and Borneo.
species_profile.habitat: Temperate moist, broadleaf forest and tropical evergreen rainforest.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Grasses, vegetables, leaves, seedlings, herbs, fruits and fungi, although invertebrates and amphibians have occasionally been recorded in the diet.
species_profile.threatened_by: Over-harvesting and exploitation for the food and pet trade, compounded by habitat destruction.
species_profile.image_title: Manouria emys phayrei by Herpetologe, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as the Greater Oriental Chevrotain, Balabac Chevrotain, Greater Mousedeer, Larger Malay Chevrotain, Larger Mousedeer, and Napu. It is marked with a vivid pattern of stripes on its pelage. It is small for a deer species, compactly built, shy, and mostly nocturnal in habit.
Using tiny, tunnel-like trails through thick brush when traveling, they rest and move at specific intervals several times a day. Extremely territorial by nature, both sexes of larger Malay mouse deer regularly mark their territories with urine, faeces, and secretions from an inter-mandibular gland under the chin. When angry, the male will beat the ground with his hooves at a rate of four times per second.
Greater mouse-deer breed throughout the year; the female spends most of her adult life pregnant. They usually produce one young per birth, after a gestation of 152–155 days. Newborn animals are well-developed and immediately able to stand; they are fully active after 30 minutes. The young stand on three legs while nursing. Both male and female become mature at age 4½ months. Their life span is up to 14 years.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam; Indonesia (Kalimantan, Sumatera); Malaysia (Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, Sarawak); Myanmar; Thailand.
species_profile.habitat: Subtropical or tropical moist lowland forest.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Fallen fruits, aquatic plants, buds, leaves, shrubs and grasses.
species_profile.threatened_by: Hunting and habitat loss.
species_profile.image_title: Greater mouse Deer  (Tragulus napu) by gary1844, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as the silvered leaf monkey or the silvery langur/lutung. It is a medium sized monkey with a long, non-prehensile tail. It has grey-tipped, dark brown or black fur, giving it a uniform silvery appearance. A crest of fur runs along the top of the head, and the hair on the cheeks is long, often obscuring the ears. The hands and feet are hairless, with dark coloured skin, and have opposable thumbs and toes. Silvery lutings are diurnal, and travel in groups of around 9-40 individuals with one adult male and many adult females communally caring for infants. Females remain in the group for life, while males leave shortly after reaching adulthood, living in small groups of their own until they can take over an established harem. Within the group, males dominate the females, and females with young dominate those without. Like other langurs, the silvery lutung has a large three-chambered stomach to digest the cellulose found in its herbivorous diet.
Females range from 46 to 51 centimetres (18 to 20 in) in head-body length, with an average weight of 5.7 kilograms (13 lb) and a tail length of 67 to 75 centimetres (26 to 30 in). Males are slightly larger, from 50 to 58 centimetres (20 to 23 in) in length, with an average weight of 6.6 kilograms (15 lb) and a tail length of 67 to 75 centimetres (26 to 30 in). 
Silvery lutungs breed year round, with no clear breeding season, although each female typically gives birth no more than once every 18 to 24 months.[8] The female attracts the male by making side-to-side motions with her head, and copulation may occur several times during a bout. Unusually, females have been reported to reach menopause in the wild, and may survive up to nine years after last giving birth. 
The female gives birth to a single young after a gestation period of 181 to 200 days. The young weigh about 400 grams (14 oz), measure about 20 centimetres (7.9 in) and are well developed, with a strong grip for holding onto the mother. Silvery lutungs are born with orange fur, and with white hairless skin on the face, hands, and feet. The skin rapidly changes to the dark adult colour, but the fur does not reach the adult pattern for three to five months after birth. The young are cared for by females communally, and are not weaned for 18 months, even though the biological mother stops lactating after just 12 months.[9] The young are sexually mature almost as soon as they finish weaning, and, on average, females first give birth at 35 months of age.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam; Indonesia; Malaysia.
species_profile.habitat: A variety of primary and secondary forest types, including riverine, mangrove, swamp, montane and coastal. It is occasionally found in plantations.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Mainly folivorous, with leaves comprising 60 to 80% of the diet. However, it will also feed on fruit, seeds, flowers, and young shoots.
species_profile.who_eats_them: Humans, leopards, tigers, dholes, and some large snakes. Binturongs, civets.
species_profile.threatened_by: Disappearance of suitable lowland habitat due to land clearance (especially for oil palm plantations) and forest fires is a major threat, especially in Peninsular Malaysia and Borneo. The species is hunted in Sarawak, while in Sumatra it is heavily traded and is a popular pet.
species_profile.image_title: Silvery Lutung & Young by Truus & Zoo, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
The leopard cat’s name is derived from the leopard-like spots it has. Leopard cats are excellent swimmers. Leopard cats are solitary, except during breeding season. Some are active during the day, but most hunt at night. They are agile climbers and quite arboreal in their habits. They rest in trees, but also hide in dense thorny undergrowth on the ground. Leopard cats can swim, but seldom do so. They produce a similar range of vocalisations to the domestic cat. Leopard cats are about the size of a domestic cat, but more slender with longer legs and well-defined webs between the toes. Their small head is marked with two prominent dark stripes, their short and narrow muzzle white. There are two dark stripes running from the eyes to the ears, and smaller white streaks running from the eyes to the nose. The backs of their moderately long and rounded ears are black with a central white spot. Body and limbs are marked with black spots of varying size and color, and along the back are two to four rows of elongated spots. The tail is about half the size of their head-body-length and spotted with a few indistinct rings near the black tip. leopard cats weigh 0.55 to 3.8 kg (1.2 to 8.4 lb), have a head-body-length of 38.8 to 66 cm (15.3 to 26 in) with a 17.2 to 31 cm (6.8 to 12 in) long tail.
There is no fixed breeding period in the southern part of its range; in the colder northern range they tend to breed around March or April, when the weather is mild enough to support newborn kittens.
After a gestation period of 60–70 days, two to four kittens are born in a den, where they remain until they are a month old. The kittens weigh about 75 to 130 grams (2.6 to 4.6 oz) at birth and usually double their weight by age of two weeks. The eyes open at ten days, and the kittens start to eat solid food at 23 days. At the age of four weeks, the permanent canines appear, and the kittens begin to eat solid food.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Afghanistan; Bangladesh; Bhutan; Brunei Darussalam; Cambodia; China; Hong Kong; India; Indonesia (Jawa, Kalimantan, Sumatera); Japan (Nansei-shoto); Korea, Democratic People’s Republic of; Korea, Republic of; Lao People’s Democratic Republic; Malaysia; Myanmar; Nepal; Pakistan; Philippines; Russian Federation; Singapore; Taiwan, Province of China; Thailand; Vietnam.
species_profile.habitat: They occur in a broad spectrum of habitats, from tropical rainforest to temperate broadleaf and, marginally, coniferous forest, as well as shrub forest and successional grasslands. The northern boundaries of its range are limited by snow cover; the leopard cat avoids areas where snow is more than 10 cm deep. It is not found in the cold steppe grasslands, and generally does not occur in arid zones.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Rodents. Other small mammals, eels and fish have also been reported, as well as occasional scavenging of carrion.
species_profile.threatened_by: Hunted throughout most of its range for fur, for food, and as pets. They are also widely viewed as poultry pests and killed in retribution. Leopard cats can hybridize with domestic cats, as is shown by the popular domestic breed, the “safari cat”. Habitat loss and fragmentation is still a major threat across most of its Asian range.
species_profile.image_title: Leopard Cat Prionailurus bengalensis borneoensis by berniedup, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as the Lesser Malay Chevrotain and the Lesser Oriental Chevrotain.  It is the smallest known hoofed mammal, at a mature size as little as around 45 cm (18 inches) and 2 kg (4.4 lb). Lesser mouse deer have soft reddish-brown fur marked with a pattern of pale spots or stripes running along the sides of the neck and a pale-colored underside. Unlike deer, the males have no antlers, but do sport a pair of canine teeth that can be seen projecting downward from the upper jaw like two tiny tusks. Males make use of their teeth to defend themselves and their mates against rivals.
These tiny browsers are crepuscular feeders, meaning that they prefer being active in the dim light of dusk and dawn. In their forest home, mouse deer travel along paths which resemble tunnels of thick vegetation leading to resting places and feeding areas. Males are very territorial and they regularly mark their territories with scent glands found under their chins.
Female mouse deer may give birth to a single fawn at any time of year. Like other hoofed animals, newborn fawns are precocial and stand within thirty minutes of being born. The does wean their fawns at around twelve weeks. The fawns can breed at five to six months, and may live for twelve years.
Sang kancil (pronounced: Kahn-cheel), the diminutive but wise mouse deer, holds a place of pride in Malay and Indonesian folklore. The tiny hero is cunning and intelligent, and able to prevail over larger tyrants and foes. In these tales, the only thing “lesser” about the lesser mouse deer is his size.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam; Cambodia; Indonesia; Lao People’s Democratic Republic; Malaysia; Myanmar; Singapore; Thailand; Vietnam.
species_profile.habitat: Lowland/foothill primary and secondary forests as well as cultivated areas up to 600 m in elevation (Semiadi and Boeadi pers. comm.). The habitat of this species is a mosaic of riverine, seasonal swamp and dry undulating country, vegetated predominantly by legumes and dipterocarps. In Sabah, they also inhabit mangrove forest.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Shoots, young leaves, fungi and fallen fruits in the tall forest of the lowlands.
species_profile.who_eats_them: The natural predators of the lesser mouse deer include crocodiles, snakes, birds of prey and all forest cats. They are taken by humans throughout most of their range for meat and skins.
species_profile.threatened_by: Trade, hunting and habitat loss and destruction.
species_profile.image_title: 3557/ Mindre mushjort / Lesser Mouse-deer (Tragulus kanchil) by zooadmin, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also named the crab eating macaque. They have pinkish-brown faces and the fur on their heads sweeps back over their forehead, often creating a crest of hair on the top of their heads. Males have mustaches and cheek whiskers that frame their faces while females have beards as well as cheek whiskers. Both males and females have white coloration on the eyelids near the nose. The defining characteristic, for which they are named, is their extraordinarily long tail that is almost always longer than their height from head to rump, and ranges in length between 400 and 655 mm (1.31 and 2.15 ft). These macaques are primarily arboreal and can leap distances between trees up to five meters.
Long-tailed macaques sleep in trees along the river and are particular about choosing their roosting sites. Each group sleeps in its own tree and individuals huddle together when they sleep to maintain body temperature. They sleep toward the edge of the branches near the top or crown of the tree and preferentially choose branches that overhang the river. Long-tailed macaques are excellent swimmers, and this may be a predator avoidance technique: if they are threatened, they simply can escape by dropping to the water and swimming to safe.
Reproductive output is linked to dominance status among female long-tailed macaques. Sexual maturity in females is reached at four years of age, males at 7. About 80% of the infants born into a long-tailed macaque group are sired by the alpha male. Females give birth to singletons and the interbirth interval averages 18 months.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Bangladesh; Brunei Darussalam; Cambodia; India (Andaman Is., Nicobar Is.); Indonesia; Lao People’s Democratic Republic; Malaysia; Myanmar; Philippines; Singapore; Thailand; Timor-Leste; Vietnam.
species_profile.habitat: The species is extremely tolerant of a range of habitats, including mangrove and swamp forests, and can be found in agricultural areas near forest (secondary growth, secondary forest, and primary forest).
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Fruit, insects, stems, young and mature leaves, flowers, seeds, grass, mushrooms, invertebrates, bird eggs, clay and bark. crabs and have also been seen eating frogs, shrimp and octopus.
species_profile.who_eats_them: Pythons, monitor lizards, raptors, large cats, and, in some areas, feral dogs.
species_profile.threatened_by: In mainland Southeast Asia, such as in Cambodia and Viet Nam, females are taken into breeding facilities and males are exported internationally primarily for use in laboratory research. A potential related issue is the release of confiscated long-tailed macaques from the border area of Viet Nam and China (which is where most of the current international trade is being recorded) into the native range of other macaque species. In the Philippines, the species is subject to a high level of hunting, where it is taken for local consumption and hunted for sport. It is also persecuted as a pest. Habitat loss is also a localised threat, but the species can persist in a variety of habitats and very adaptable.
species_profile.image_title: macaca fascicularis by Joachim S. Müller, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
These porcupines ranges in color from brownish-yellow to nearly black. Their
bodies are about 18 inches long and are covered with thick, sharp quills, which are longer
and lighter in color than their fur. Their long tails are also quilled, but have bare tips for
better grip. Both hind- and forefeet have four digits with long curved claws for climbing.
They have a bald, bulbous nose which aids their excellent sense of smell; however, they
have poor vision.
The long tailed porcupines are arboreal, spending most of their time climbing among the
treetops in their forest homes. They are nocturnal, spending their days sleeping in
hollows or tangled vines high above the forest floor, awakening at night to forage. They
rarely drink water, but obtain all they need from their diet. When confronted, they may
stomp their feet and shake their quills, making a rattling noise. Like all porcupines, their
barbed quills are not thrown or shot at predators, but release quite easily when the porcupine is tense. 
The female gives birth to a singlet after a 203-day gestation
period. Babies are born year-round, and have reddish hair and soft quills, which harden in
about a week. They are born with their eyes open and are able to climb within a few hours
of birth. They are weaned around 10 weeks, and will sexually maturity in 1.5 years.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam; Indonesia (Kalimantan); Malaysia (Sabah, Sarawak).
species_profile.habitat: Lowland forest, but also found in secondary and degraded habitat.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Eat fruit, flowers, leaves, shoots, and the inner bark of trees.
species_profile.threatened_by: Hunting by humans.
species_profile.image_title: Long-tailed Porcupine by siwild, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as the Sunda stink-badger. nocturnal, sheltering in underground burrows during the day. The head and body are about 15 in. long, and the tail no more than an inch; the fur is dark brown, with the top of the head, neck and a broad dorsal stripe, white. Like the skunk, this animal can eject the foetid secretion of the anal glands. The stink badgers are rather small, short and stocky animals, They have elongated muzzles, pig-like noses, very small external ears and tails, and short but muscular legs with long, curved claws on the forefeet. Mydaus javanensis, measures from 34 to 51 cm from nose to tail base, with a tail measuring from 3.5 to 7.5 cm; its weight varies from about 1.3 to 3.6 kg.
Both species have body fur which typically is predominantly dark brown (M. javanensis) or cocoa brown (M. marchei) to black or blackish in colour. The Indonesian stink badger has a large patch of white or yellowish hair on the top of its head, and a stripe of the same colour extending from this along the spine to the tail (though sometimes the stripe is not continuous); the hairs of the tail are also white or yellowish. 
Litter size is suspected to be two to three.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Indonesia (Jawa, Kalimantan, Sumatera); Malaysia (Sabah, Sarawak).
species_profile.habitat: Secondary forests and open grounds such as gardens adjacent to forests.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Bird eggs, carrion, insects, worms, and plants.
species_profile.who_eats_them: Javan Hawk Eagle,  civets, feral cats and, on Sumatra, the tiger.
species_profile.threatened_by: On Java, the anal gland secretion is used to make perfume, and some rural people eat the flesh of this species. It is also used in traditional medicine to cure fever or rheumatism.
species_profile.image_title: TELEDU(MALAY BADGER) Mydaus javanensis by dennisikon, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts: Also known as oriental civet. The word ‘civet’ is derived from an Arabic word, ‘zabad’, which is the name of an oily fluid secreted from the scent glands of most members of the family Viverridae (8). Many civet species use scent marking as a means of territory defence Malay civets are solitary, omnivorous and primarily terrestrial. Malay civets were mainly nocturnal, with some periods of rest during the night; daytime rest sites were within dense ground cover. The Malaysian Civet has short grey or tawny fur with a pattern of black spots arranged in rows all along its body. The tail is banned. The Malaysian Civet is most well known for its distinct stripping along its neck and throat. The usual markings are three black stripes and two white stripes. The civet also has a mane of longer hair that runs down its back. An unusual black stripe runs the length of the mane. The feet of the Malaysian Civet are black. They have five toes on each foot with retractable claws located on the third and fourth digits of their forefeet. The Malaysian Civet measures roughly 585 to 950 mm in length and weights approximately 11 to 24 lbs. They live around 5 to 15 years Malaysian civets come together only for mating. Males viverrids have a baculum or bone found in the penis. The male leaves the female shortly after mating takes place. She will then dig a burrow in the ground or make a nest from the dense vegetation to give birth in. One to four young are born in a litter. The female will give birth to a litter twice a year. When the young are born they are completely dependent on their mother. Their eyes are closed but they do have some hair to help keep them warm. They will drink their mothers milk for for at least one month, after that the mother will begin to wean the babies teaching them how to hunt on their own.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Indonesia (Kalimantan, Maluku – Introduced, Sulawesi, Sumatera); Malaysia (Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, Sarawak); Philippines; Singapore.
species_profile.habitat: Primary and secondary forests, cultivated land and the outskirts of villages (Nowak, 1999; Colon, 2002; Jennings et al., 2006). It is found from sea level to at least 1,200 m.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Small mammals, birds, frogs, snakes and insects. They will also partake of eggs and fruit if they are available. Some have even been seen digging up roots.
species_profile.threatened_by: Snaring and other forms of ground-level trapping, and hunting with dogs, however, the limited survey in areas heavily used by people suggests it is rather well able to persist at general levels of threat. The species is occasionally hunted for food and treated as a pest as it raids poultry.
species_profile.image_title: Borneo104 by croix.gagnon, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
The marbled cat is a small, tree living cat. They are similar in size to a domestic cat and have characteristics comparable to their close relative the clouded leopard. When young their fur is a mottled brown colour which develops into the adult cryptic colouration at around four months of age, with a base of brownish-yellow covered in large blotches with pale centres and black outlines.
Little is known about their lifestyle as they are rarely seen in the wild. They are believed to be solitary and nocturnal. Due to their wary nature accounts of their reproductive behaviour in the wild is unknown.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: From northern India and Nepal, through south-eastern Asia to Borneo and Sumatra. Distribution has been compiled mainly from single observations so their range may be wider than currently known.
species_profile.habitat: Moist and mixed deciduous evergreen tropical forest
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Mainly birds and arboreal small mammals including tree squirrels, tree shrews, small primates, rats, mice and fruit bats. Other prey includes lizards, frogs and insects.
species_profile.threatened_by: Habitat loss through deforestation, logging, oil palm and other plantations including human settlements and agriculture. Valued for its skin, meat and bones.
species_profile.image_title: Marbled Cat-Pardofelis marmorata by Bram Demeulemeester - Birdguiding Philippines, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Also known as the Red Leaf Monkey. A small, red to reddish-orange monkey that is endemic to Borneo and adjacent Karimata Island. They are tree living and diurnal. Groups have home ranges that overlap with others but will have a central area where their sleeping site is located. The size of their home range is dependent on group size. They are territorial and chase other groups away.
They live in a unimale (single male) groups with one or more females, subadults, juveniles and infants. Males generally disperse after adolescence and will travel solitarily or in all males groups before finding their own unimale group. There is no dominance system in females and they give birth to a single infant.
When threatened the male will sound the alarm telling the group to move quickly, they will move a short distance before freezing in order to reduce the chance of predation.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Found in Borneo and Karimata.
species_profile.habitat: Lowland forest (not above 2000m), along the edge of forests and rivers.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Young leaves, seeds and some pulpy, seedy fruits but generally not ripe succulent fruit as this affects their stomach pH. Diet can vary throughout the year with the availability of food stuffs.
species_profile.threatened_by: Habitat loss through deforestation for oil palm plantations, hunting for meat and traditional ‘medicine’.
species_profile.image_title: Red Leaf Monkey by mishko2007, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
A solitary, nocturnal animal that sleeps in the treetops during the day, they are partly arboreal and omnivorous. They have short orange-brown to grey fur with no spots or strips but have darker (black) feet. A distinguishing feature is their face mask of black and white strips and spots.
The female will have two litters of one to four young per year who will be fully grown by the age of four months; the male will have no involvement in their upbringing.
When alarmed by predators the civet will spray a secretion from its anal gland to dissuade predators, in a similar fashion to skunks.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Northern India, South eastern Asia and China, as well as Borneo, Sumatra and Taiwan.
species_profile.habitat: Both evergreen and deciduous forest.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Mainly fruit but also small rodents, birds and insects (likes figs, mangoes, bananas and leaves).
species_profile.who_eats_them: Tigers, leopards, birds of prey and humans.
species_profile.threatened_by: Habitat loss, and hunted and trapped for the commercial food trade in China (although not a major threat as they are arboreal and can avoid traps and snares). Believed to have been a carrier of SARS.
species_profile.image_title: 多摩動物園 108　Paguma larvata by urasimaru, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
The moonrat is generally white all over (hence the name) with the odd black hair scattered throughout its short, coarse fur. They have long, narrow bodies with pointy snouts and naked tails. Despite looking similar to a large rat they are not rats but instead related to shrews. They have a distinct pungent odour which smells like strong ammonia, this is used to mark their territory and ward off invaders and predators.
They are nocturnal and live on the forest floor, during the day they will lie under logs, roots or in abandoned burrows. They live alone and the females give birth to two infants at a time, in a nest made of leaves. They have a lifespan of approximately five years and are relatively common in suitable habitats.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Southern Myanmar, Thailand, Malaysia, Borneo and Sumatra.
species_profile.habitat: Lowland forests including very moist areas such as mangroves and swamp forests, also have been found in hilly forests.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Omnivores that feed on worms, insects, crabs and other invertebrates found in moist places. Also eat fruit, and occasionally frogs or fish.
species_profile.threatened_by: Deforestation for oil palm and forest fires, however they are fairly adaptable most likely not to be a serious threat.
species_profile.image_title: Moonrat by siwild, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
This species is diurnal and arboreal, only occasionally descending to the ground to feed. They are also known as the tricolour squirrel and are one of the most colourful of all squirrels. There are more than 10 subspecies recognised across Borneo and its neighbouring countries and there are variations in colour and patterning. A well recognised colouration is the back and tail being a glossy black, the arms and belly a bright chestnut red and a white band that extends along both sides of the animal from nose to tail base.
They are solitary individuals that communicate through trilling, whistling and raising their tails. The tail is also used for balance when running and climbing, a rudder while jumping and for wrapping to keep warm at night. They are excellent at climbing and jumping and have sharp claws that assist with clinging to tree trunks. They are also capable of jumping considerable distances.
Sexual maturity occurs at the age of one and they have up to 3 litters per year of 1-4 offspring who can leave the nest after 6 weeks.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Sumatra and Borneo.
species_profile.habitat: Lowland and montane forest, dense rainforests and will tolerate secondary forest, will occasionally enter fruit orchards or plantations.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Eats fruits, nuts, seeds, flowers, insects and bird eggs, is considered a pest of oil palm and coconut plantations.
species_profile.threatened_by: The remaining habitat of this species is very small as plantations have replaced a large part of its habitat and in parts of Sarawak they are very heavily hunted for pets.
species_profile.image_title: Striking a pose by greytama, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
The Sambar deer are Crepuscular (i.e. active at morning and dusk) and nocturnal in habit, they are most easily spotted at the forest margins where they feed on young grass shoots. They frequent natural salt licks, particularly adult males who need minerals to promote growth of their antlers.
Male Sambar are among the largest of Southeast Asia’s deer, with a head-body length of up to 2 metres and weighing up to 260 kg. The fur is brown to grey-brown, the tail dark and the underside of the tail and rump area whitish. The antlers of the male usually have three tines (points). In addition to grass shoots they feed on vines and fallen fruits. Herds are small with up to 4 individuals, and a single fawn is born after a gestation period of 8 months.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Bangladesh; Bhutan; Brunei Darussalam; Cambodia; China (Guangxi, Guizhou, Hainan, Hunan, Jiangxi, Sichuan, Yunnan); India; Indonesia (Sumatera); Lao People’s Democratic Republic; Malaysia; Myanmar; Nepal; Sri Lanka; Taiwan, Province of China; Thailand; Vietnam.
species_profile.habitat: Can live in a wide range of habitats but are now generally confined to primary and mature secondary forests.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Documented to eat 130–180 species of plants in India alone. Sambar grazes or browses depending upon the forage available at that time.
species_profile.who_eats_them: Big cats; specifically Tigers and Leopards.
species_profile.threatened_by: Habitat encroachment and hunting
species_profile.image_title: IMG_0500 Sambar (Cervus unicolor), Kanha, India 07Feb10 by Lathers, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Little is known about this mongoose species as it is rarely seen, however it is endemic to places where found and the population could be threatened.
They are a red-brown to black colour with black limbs and a greyish head with black spots on the chin. However, in some regions they can be white or yellowish-red.
They are approximately two metres long with a tail that is a third of its body length. They have a semi-aquatic lifestyle.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Found in Southeast Asia and native to Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia and Malaysia.
species_profile.habitat: Found near rivers, in lowland primary and secondary forest and plantations.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Eats snakes, fish and crustaceans (shellfish), majority of its food is found in aquatic environments.
species_profile.threatened_by: Unknown, but eaten in some parts of Sarawak and considered a pest in some agricultural areas.
species_profile.image_title: Short-tailed Mongoose by siwild, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
The Sun bear is the smallest bear and is named from its distinctive sun-like golden-coloured chest patch. They have short fur; deep black-brown colour. They prefer to live alone.
Sun bears are mainly active at night and rest during the day on a platform of branches which it makes high in the trees. They are skilful climbers and as agile as a monkey. They have a very long tongue for extracting honey and insects from deep crevices in the trees.
Female bears use cavities of large hollow trees as birthing sites. They most often give birth to one cub and will suckle it for about 18 months. Females reach sexual maturity at about three years and males at four years. 
All year round food availability means that Sun bears do not hibernate!
species_profile.where_do_they_live: South-east Asia: Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, China, India, Indonesia, Lao Peoples Democratic Republic, Malaysia, Myanmar, Thailand and Vietnam.
species_profile.habitat: Lowland tropical forest.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Fruits, honey, bee larvae, ants, small vertebrates such as lizards. They are omnivores.
species_profile.who_eats_them: Tigers, leopards, birds of prey and humans.
species_profile.threatened_by: Habitat loss from deforestation and commercial hunting.
species_profile.image_title: Sun bear (Helarctos malayanus) by ucumari, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
The pangolin is a timid, cautious and solitary animal which forages during the night, resting in hollows either in or at the base of trees during the day. They move slowly on all fours and walk on the knuckles of their fore claws.
They have an excellent sense of smell which assists with locating insects and thick powerful claws used for digging or destructing termite mounds. Although terrestrial they will climb trees in search of ant’s nests, they are fairly skilful climbers and use their prehensile tail to cling to branches and assist with this.
Their body is covered by rows of scales formed by compressed, fibrous hair like material, these scales act like armour. The under parts lack scales and are therefore more vulnerable. Pangolins will roll into a tight ball when threatened so that their armoured tail and body protects their under parts. They coil up so tightly that it is almost impossible to unroll them and the scales become erect and shudder adding to the defence. Additionally they are known to secrete an acrid liquid from their anal region.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao People’s Demographic Republic, Malaysia, Myanmar, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, and Borneo.
species_profile.habitat: Primary and secondary lowland forest, cultivated areas including gardens and plantations, grasslands, thick bush and barren hilly areas.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: They are specialised feeders that eat ants and termites. On average a pangolin may eat up to 200,000 ants per day; they have no requirement for teeth as insects are swallowed whole and gathered using its sticky tongue.
species_profile.threatened_by: Major threats are through the rapid loss and deterioration of suitable habitat. They are also hunted for local use and for the international trade of their scales, skin and meat. Prices have escalated since 1990 meaning on the international market in some areas people will pay US$95/kg .
species_profile.image_title: Pangolin hiding behind a tree by kwokwai76, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
Monitor lizards have long, slender, muscular bodies with a narrow head, long neck and well developed legs equipped with long toes and claws. They also have a long, powerful, sideways compressed tail which has a keel on the top to assist with swimming. The tail can be up to 1½ times its body length. They can grow up to a maximum weight of 50kg but most will only reach half this size.
They are typically an amphibious animal which swims confidently over long distances and has the ability to stay under water for 30 minutes. This lizard is active during the day and will often spend the night in water.
Their colouration is either drab grey, dark brown or olive with yellow or white spots. These spots can be arranged in circles giving the appearance of strips across its back. The colour varies with age and sub species. 
They are not territorial but can be very aggressive and will use their tail and jaw when fighting. They live solitarily and the young are extremely secretive and rarely seen.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Found in Sri Lanka, India, Indochina, Indonesia and Malay Peninsula.
species_profile.habitat: Inhabits a variety of natural habitats but most important are mangrove vegetation, swamp and wetlands all at altitude of less than 1000m. Also observed in agricultural areas and cities with canal systems.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: They are extreme carnivores and will eat almost anything. Diet consists of birds and their eggs, small mammals (rats, monkeys and squirrels), fish, lizards, frogs, snakes, crocodile eggs and juveniles.
species_profile.threatened_by: They are hunted for their skin (leather trade), meat and fat which is used in traditional medicine.
species_profile.image_title: Monitor Lizard (Varanus Salvator) by Keith Kelly, on Flickr

species_profile.animal_facts:
An Asian species of marten that is a medium sized carnivore related to the otter and weasel. They are fearless, agile and fast moving and primarily diurnal. However, they are sometimes said to be largely or entirely nocturnal as they will hunt at night and increase their nocturnal activity during lunar nights (this is ±7 days around the full moon). They hunt mostly on the ground but are perfectly capable of climbing trees.
Distinguished by their bright and attractive colouration, a mixture of black, white, golden-yellow and brown, their fur is relatively short and has a strong odour. The head is small with a pointed muzzle and round ears and the body is elongated with hind limbs that are more muscular than the forelimbs, the tail is long and thick and can be more than half its body length. 
They live in groups of 2-3 or on occasions have been seen in groups of 5-7 but this is rare. Their litter sizes will be up to five young and gestation is for 220-290 days. They have a lifespan of approximately 14 years.
species_profile.where_do_they_live: Native to countries in South-east Asia including India, China, Thailand, Borneo, Cambodia and Indonesia.
species_profile.habitat: Primary and secondary lowland and montane forests less that 3000m, type of habitat can vary depending on the region they are from.
species_profile.what_do_they_eat: Primarily a carnivore but does have omnivorous tendencies, food items include squirrels, birds, snakes and lizards, insects, frogs, eggs, fruit, nectar and berries, will also eat honey and bees giving it a very extensive diet.
species_profile.threatened_by: There are no significant threats at the population level. However they are tied to forest areas and hunted heavily for their fur in Siberia and Korea, this is not a global threat. They are easily habituated to humans and not afraid to take waste from bins, this could make them easy targets and to become classified as a pest.
species_profile.image_title: Martre à gorge jaune de Sibérie (Martes flavigula aterrima) by Maxime Thué, on Flickr
